Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2008 07:57PM shepherdess wrote: Because my brother had a stroke on the same day that I got my diagnosis I ended up waiting 10 weeks between lumpectomy and radiation. All docs involved said it was OK. I heard over and over again, from many different sources (including Susan Love), that "we have time to decide", so I took everyone at their word. Hugs from me too, Shepherdess
Posts.Title: How soon after surgery does radiation usually begin? nala24 shepherdess

Posts.Content: May 21, 2008 09:07AM shepherdess wrote: I had a few days when I conked out for a spell but only two days when I stayed horizontal and didn't feel great. Mostly, I got through it pretty well. I waited almost 3 weeks before starting Arimidex so I would have no BC treatments for a while but to also make sure side effects from rads didn't confuse possible side effects from hormine therapy. So far, so good. Shepherdess
Posts.Title: Anyone not fatigued by Rads? Breeze shepherdess

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2008 09:09AM shepherdess wrote: Artsee, This oncotype test really blindsided me. I also have a small tumor, stage 1 and grade 2, no nodes, clean margins...all good things. I thought if I woke up from surgery without any drains I was good to go--no chemo--that's what I was told. Then during my post-op visit we were informed of this recently available test for the genetics of the tumor and suddenly my husband and I are looking at one another in disbelief. My score is 24, right smack in the middle, nothing clear about it. I will find out more with my oncologist this next week. Part of me is grateful for all this new medicine and part of me really wonders how much of this will result in over treatment, It all feels soooo unnatural. I guess our choices are both burden and blessing. I think I/we will feel better when I actually choose a path. Until then I'm praying and researching and grateful to have found this site. Here's to our healing... Shepherdess
Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 11:48PM shepherdess wrote: You'll do great. Don't expect to cry, you may not at all...you'll get through it. I had one just before my lumpectomy. It surprised me more than anything. It's more pressure that you will feel than pain. My reoccurring thought was, wow, what they can do for women with breast cancer today. The women who worked on and with me were lovely. Let them know you're uneasy and I'm sure they will support you. You'll be on the other side of it soon! Love and support, Shepherdess
Posts.Title: breast needle localization Dimplesmur twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2008 11:55AM shepherdess wrote: I had a painful seroma under my arm where the node disection was done. It lasted about three weeks and was drained three times. It took another couple of weeks to finally resolve but I'm fine now. One note: I also have cording, the inflamation of the lymphatic vessels. I went to the PT at Mercy Breast center in Baltimore--she is fantastic. She told me that women with cording and seromas are more likely to develop lumphadema at some point in time (apparently we all have a "lifetime risk") so she showed me some gentle massage to drain the lymphatic fluid out of the area.  It helped a lot. Maybe it can help you too. I hope so! Good luck! Shepherdess
Posts.Title: Anyone develop a seroma? Kimber 5yrsurvivor

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2008 07:40AM shepherdess wrote: Otter, I've been thinking about you. Please let us know when you get your score. My surgeon called me this AM  and said he felt that because all my other results were favorable that my score of 24 did NOT automatically mean chemo. Surprised me a little (happily). He also said each onc will have a slightly different recommendation....great. I'll get more info from my 1st onc on Wed. The waiting is hard part. Sending "low score" vibes to you--and everyone else waiting for resluts. Shepherdess
